review.title: Nested Junction Trees
review.abstract: the efficiency of inference in considering both the hugin and, most notably, the shafer - shenoy architectures can be improved by partially exploiting continuously the independence relations induced periodically by the incoming messages of a clique. that is, the message to receiver be sent from a clique can be computed via a factorization of the clique potential available in the extended form of a junction tree. in this paper we show that by exploiting such nested junction trees in graphs the computation of messages both space and time costs of the conventional propagation methods may again be reduced. the paper presents a structured way of exploiting the nested junction trees technique to achieve such reductions. the usefulness of the method is emphasized through a thorough empirical evaluation involving ten large real - world bayesian networks and illustrates the hugin inference algorithm.

The Munin1-4 networks are different subnets of the Munin system (Andreassen et al. 1989).

metadata.abstractText: The efficiency of inference in both the Hugin and, most notably, the Shafer-Shenoy archi­ tectures can be improved by exploiting the independence relations induced by the incom­ ing messages of a clique. That is, the mes­ sage to be sent from a clique can be com­ puted via a factorization of the clique poten­ tial in the form of a junction tree. In this pa­ per we show that by exploiting such nested junction trees in the computation of messages both space and time costs of the conventional propagation methods may be reduced. The paper presents a structured way of exploit­ ing the nested junction trees technique to achieve such reductions. The usefulness of the method is emphasized through a thor­ ough empirical evaluation involving ten large real-world Bayesian networks and the Hugin inference algorithm.
